newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Washington Post front - May 8.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Washington Post front - May 8.

text.p: The Washington Post carried the following stories on its front page on May 8:
WASHINGTON - The Army accused the most senior enlisted man Sgt. Maj. of the Army Gene McKinney of having committed adultery with a female soldier and propositioning three other servicewomen.

SPOTSYLVANIA, Va. - Detectives intensified their search for the driver of a white pickup truck seen cruising the Lisk sisters' neighborhood before their disappearance, while FBI divers and other investigators scoured a river about 35 miles away where the girls' bodies were found.

SPOTSYLVANIA, Va. - The deaths of two sisters put residents on alert in this rural county where scared children play computer games behind locked doors and door-to-door salesmen are reported to the sheriff.

WASHINGTON - Thirteen weeks before he died, Jack Kent Cooke changed his will to deny fourth wife Marlene Ramallo Cooke any part of his estate, but the document creates a charitable foundation to help gifted and underprivileged children.
KINSHASA, Zaire - The president Zairians revile left the country and may not return, while rebel forces tightened a noose around the capital.

WASHINGTON - Switzerland served as Nazi Germany's chief foreign source of credit and equipment during World War II, sustaining Adolf Hitler's war machine long after German financial resources were exhausted, according to a scathing U.S. government report.

WASHINGTON - More than four years after overwhelmingly rejecting a referendum that would have established the death penalty in the District, a majority of residents now favor capital punishment for those who kill police officers, according to a new poll.
